entry.title: Re: In the AW01N screen, the incorrect value is displayed...
entry.content: The field Iâ€™m referring to should not be considered as â€œposting depreciation only.â€ This field is not supposed to post depreciation at all. Instead, it should simply display the combined total of two reporting-only value fields. While the asset values are displayed correctly in the asset reports, the AW01N screen shows this field incorrectly. The issue is specifically related to the way it is displayed on AW01N.

entry.content:
Hi @BorisZarske 

Thanks for the clarification. Weâ€™ve set everything up on a shared subaccount, as you suggested.

Regarding the credentials: I initially used my own user for testing, but I now need to switch to a proper technical user. I havenâ€™t found a clear step-by-step guide on how to create one, and the official documentation is somewhat indirect on this point.

Do you know if such a tutorial exists, or where I could find reliable instructions?

Thanks in advance,


Theo

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
@neilaspin  We have aligned the exam even more closely with a realistic business scenario based on the latest features of the generative AI hub covered in the learning journey and exam participantsâ€™ feedback received so far.

We have also improved the system landscape stability and capacity to cater to the huge interest shown by learners in this certification.

Finally, we have worked on the duration of the activities to give participants a better opportunity to address the given scenario more appropriately within the stipulated time.

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
Hi @Paul6110,
The E_S4CPE exam will continue to be offered. The underlying courses are still available and are continuously updated. They are not retired. We are currently working on publishing a new learning journey that clarifies the recommended courses to take in preparation for the certification. The certification description page will be updated accordingly:

  • Exploring SAP Cloud ERP

  • Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

  • Introducing RISE with SAP Methodology for SAP Partners and Customers

Both certifications are valid and have their rightful place. They are targeting different learner roles. As you pointed out, C_S4PM2 is recommended to project managers, whereas E_S4CPE is recommended for implementation consultants.
Best regards
Nadine

entry.title: Adding Shell Plugin to SAP Fiori CAP Application and Deploying to Cloud Portal Service
entry.content:
Introduction

Shell plugins in SAP Fiori launchpad allow you to extend the standard functionality of the launchpad shell. This comprehensive guide walks you through the process of creating and deploying a shell plugin CAP application to the SAP Cloud Portal service.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Business Application Studio or VS Code with SAP extensions
  • Access to SAP BTP account with Cloud Portal service
  • Basic knowledge of UI5 and CAP development
  • Fiori Generator tools installed

Step 1: Create Basic UI Using Fiori Generator

First, generate a basic Fiori application using the Fiori Generator:

Step 2: Clean Up Generated Files

Delete all files except the following essential ones:

  • manifest.json
  • Component.js
  • index.html
  • i18n folder

Step 3: Modify index.html

Update your index.html file to support the shell plugin configuration:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html lang="en">

<head>

    <meta charset="UTF-8">

    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">

    <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge">

    <title>Shell Plugin</title>

   

    <style>

        html, body, #container, #container-uiarea {

            height: 100%;

            margin: 0;

            padding: 0;

            overflow: hidden;

        }

    </style>

   

    <script

        id="sap-ui-bootstrap"

        src="https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/1.108.4/resources/sap-ui-core.js"

        data-sap-ui-theme="sap_fiori_3"

        data-sap-ui-resourceroots='{"shellplugin": "./"}'

        data-sap-ui-onInit="module:shellplugin/ComponentSupport"

        data-sap-ui-async="true"

        data-sap-ui-preload="async">

    </script>

</head>

<body class="sapUiBody sapUiSizeCompact" id="content">

    <div data-sap-ui-component

         data-name="shellplugin"

         data-id="container"

         data-settings='{"id":"shellplugin"}'

         data-handle-validation="true">

    </div>

</body>

</html>

Step 4: Update Component.js - Change to AppComponent

Modify your Component.js file to change the controller from UIComponent to AppComponent:

sap.ui.define(["sap/fe/core/AppComponent"], function (AppComponent) {

    "use strict";

   

    return AppComponent.extend("shellplugin.Component", {

        metadata: {

            manifest: "json"

        },

       

        init: function () {

            // Call parent init

            AppComponent.prototype.init.apply(this, arguments);

            console.log("âœ… Plugin is working!");

           

            // Get DAS service

            const oDAS = this.getShellService("ShellNavigation");

           

            // DAS not available case

            if (!window.das_props_hostname) {

                console.warn("âš ï¸ DAS not available - das_props_hostname missing");

                return;

            }

           

            console.warn("âœ… DAS name not found [das_props_botname missing]!");

           

            this.waitForShellAndAddStyleButton();

        },

       

        waitForShellAndAddStyleButton: function () {

            // DAS properties

            window.das_env =

                "YOUR_ENV_URL";

           

            // Create script tag

            const script = document.createElement("script");

            script.setAttribute("data-bot-name", window.das_props_botname);

            script.setAttribute("data-expander-type", "CUSTOM");

            script.setAttribute("id", "das");

            script.setAttribute("src",

                "data:text/javascript;base64,<YOUR_BASE64_ENCODED_SCRIPT>");

           

            script.onload = () => {

                if (!window.das?.setClientTheme) {

                    console.error("das.setClientTheme not available");

                }

            };

           

            document.head.appendChild(script);

        }

    });

});

Key Changes:

  • Changed from UIComponent to AppComponent
  • Used "use strict" for better code quality
  • Extended plugins.Component in the return statement

Step 5: Write Web Client Bridge Code in Component.js

The web client bridge code (shown above) handles:

  • Shell service integration
  • DAS (Digital Assistant Service) properties configuration
  • Dynamic script loading
  • Client theme management

This code checks for DAS availability and dynamically loads the required scripts for integration.

Step 6: Add Cross Navigation Details in manifest.json

Update your manifest.json to include cross navigation configuration:

{

    "_version": "1.49.0",

    "sap.app": {

        "id": "shellplugin",

        "type": "component",

        "title": "Shell Plugin Application",

        "applicationVersion": {

            "version": "1.0.0"

        }

    },

    "sap.ui5": {

        "rootView": {

            "viewName": "shellplugin.view.App",

            "type": "XML",

            "id": "app"

        },

        "dependencies": {

            "minUI5Version": "1.108.0",

            "libs": {

                "sap.ui.core": {},

                "sap.m": {},

                "sap.ui.layout": {},

                "sap.f": {}

            }

        },

        "contentDensities": {

            "compact": true,

            "cozy": true

        }

    },

    "sap.fiori": {

        "type": "plugin"

    },

    "sap.platform.cf": {

        "oAuthScopes": []

    }

}

Important Properties:

  • Set "type": "plugin" in the sap.fiori section
  • Include necessary UI5 library dependencies
  • Configure application version and ID

Step 7: Add Shell Plugin Details in CommonDataModel.json

Create or update CommonDataModel.json payload:

{

                "appId": "plugins",

                "vizId": "Shell-plugin"

              },

Step 8: Add Bootstrap Details in ushellConfig

Configure the Unified Shell (ushell) in CommonDataModel.json in businessApps:

"bootstrapPlugins": {

                  "BUILT_IN_SUPPORT": {

                    "component": "plugins",

                    "url": "../plugins",

                    "self": {

                      "name": "plugins"

                    }

                  }

                }

              },

Bootstrap Configuration:

  • Define plugin component and URL
  • Set renderer type as RendererExtensions
  • Configure application registration in Fiori Launchpad

Deployment to Cloud Portal Service

Step 1: Build the Application

# Build MTA archive

mbt build

Step 2: Deploy to Cloud Foundry

# Login to Cloud Foundry

cf login

 

# Deploy the mtar file

cf deploy mta_archives/your_app_1.0.0.mtar

Step 3: Configure in Portal Service

  1. Open SAP Cloud Portal service
  2. Navigate to Provider Manager
  3. Add a new Content Provider pointing to your deployed application
  4. Create a new site or update existing site
  5. Add the shell plugin to the site settings
  6. Assign roles to users who need access

Step 4: Test the Plugin

  1. Open your Fiori Launchpad
  2. Check browser console for the "âœ… Plugin is working!" message
  3. Verify that the plugin functionality is active

Troubleshooting

Common Issues

Plugin not loading:

  • Check manifest.json has correct "type": "plugin"
  • Verify Component.js extends AppComponent correctly
  • Check browser console for errors

DAS not available:

  • Verify das_props_hostname is set
  • Check script URL in waitForShellAndAddStyleButton
  • Ensure network access to external resources

 

 

Conclusion

You've successfully created and deployed a shell plugin for SAP Fiori launchpad. This plugin extends the standard launchpad functionality and can be customized further based on your business requirements.

Happy Coding! ğŸš€

entry.title: Re: Turning SAP Data into Process Intelligence: The Future of Seamless Connectivity
entry.content:
Hi,

we did a little bit of testing and have some feedback regarding this:

  • The Source Object Name is transferred to Signavio Process Intelligence, instead of the Target Object Name. Further, whithin Signavio Source Data I cannot change the Alias of the Replication Flows. Therefore I am stuck with the Source Object Name, which may lead to trouble. Allowing Alias within Signavio should be sufficient.
  • In Signavio one Source Data refers to one Replication Flow. Once a Replication Flow has been assigned to a Source Data, it will disappear in the selection screen for my next Source Data. Seeing them greyed out would be nice, to keep a better overview.
  • It seems the communication is a bit buggy as of now. Changing/Deleting Replication Flows in Datasphere leads to some weird behavior in Signavio.

While it may need a little bit of tweaking here and there, this is still a very welcome addition to Signavio Process Intelligence!

Best,
Benedict

entry.title: Re: Customer stock in custody
entry.content:
Thanks, Lakshmipathi!

This isn't a consignment business. The material was sold, supplied (for now only virtually) and invoiced in SAP.

After the materials are delivered and invoiced, they must remain in our company's custody, in our warehouse, until the customer has space to receive it. Since the material is very expensive and not just a single unit, it's necessary for us to maintain visible control in SAP of each material and unit once we make the "virtual" supply to the customer. As the ownership is transferred in SAP, the control must be done off our accounting books, knowing how many units of each material we still have, what was physically delivered (how many units and when), once the material has really left our warehouse.

Hours after writing my question here, I was informed that the material has already been invoiced to the customer, so now we need to perform outbound delivery and goods issue, and then â€œre-enterâ€ all that material into SAP ASAP, to be able to do the already explained control in SAP.

Someone told me over the weekend that a special â€œcustomer plantâ€ must be created, but I'm not sure if this is the correct/best way to do it (*) and then, how the material should be entered into SAP so that it's handled the way I explain above.

(*)= If it's correct, I also don't know whatâ€™s special I need to request for the plant to be created correctly, so the material is visible and handled/tracked as non-valued (once it leaves our books in SAP).

entry.title: Re: Mvt type 601 does not check the minimum remaining she...
entry.content:
Dear @25103678,

What youâ€™re seeing is actually standard Public Cloud behawior:

  • The Set Expiration Date Check(101913) in CBC is designed for goods receipts / stock increases, not for pure goods issues
  • Movement 602 (RE goods deliv. rev.) increases stock again so system treats it like a new goods receipt, so it checks minimum remaining shelf life and throws message â€Shortfall of X days against remaining shelf life in current item (X Day)â€ if the material is below the threshold.
  • Movement 601 reduces stock no new stock is created, so the standard minimum remaining shelf life check is not called, even if you maintained Entry and check for this movement type.

Documentation below:

 

My proposal, if you really need a hard block at MVT:601 in Public Cloud, use Badi:

  1. Open Custom Logic app.
  2. Create an implementation for BADI_MMIM_CHECK_MATDOC_ITEM

 

  1. In your logic:
    • Run only for:
      • Movement type = 601
      • Relevant plants / storage locations
    • Get:
      • Posting date from the material document item.
      • Shelf-life expiration date from the item
      • Minimum Remaining Shelf Life from product master
    • If SLED < posting_date + min_rem_shelf_life THEN raise an error message.
  2. Result: GI 601 is blocked by your custom check, even though SAP standard SLED check does not run there

Best Regards,

Dawid

I have a slightly different perspective on the effective date setting.

  • Data Model Conflict: I believe using a different effective date setting implies mapping to a different Metadata Framework (MDF) object. Directly matching distinct MDF objects between Onboarding and Employee Central (EC) isn't typically supported out-of-the-box.

  • Proposed Solution: A more viable workaround would be to use the Integration Center to facilitate the data transfer and necessary transformation.

By the way, hope that SAP could incorporate background information into the Hire Template in the coming releaseğŸ˜£. This would streamline the complete hire process significantly!

entry.title: Embedded IoT is here: 5 apps that accelerate sensor to insight in SAP Asset Performance Management
entry.content:
Over the past months Early Adopter Care program participants, were gradually ramped up with additional capabilities powered by the Embedded IoT platform. With SAP Asset Performance Management 2511, we have released the Embedded IoT functionality within SAP Asset Performance Management to all our customers and partners. Customers now benefit from an end-to-end offering that spans from sensor to process action or insights, all within SAP Asset Performance Management - achieving seamless integration of data sources and monitoring of IoT-connected assets, towards establishing condition based maintenance practices.

How does this look

The launchpad of SAP Asset Performance Management now contains 5 new application tiles that are accessible to end-users depending on their assigned business roles. These tiles navigate directly to the respective applications in the IoT platform. Let's briefly run through those apps below.

 

Manage Devices

This helps you connect and manage devices efficiently. It offers a unified platform to onboard, monitor, configure, and control IoT devices throughout their lifecycleâ€”including definition of device protocols, software & configuration management, and more, depending on the capabilities of the connected device or gateway. Many industrial environments use lightweight messaging protocols (e.g., MQTT) to collect telemetry data from machines, devices, and sensors. Embedded IoT now makes it easy to ingest and process this data as it arrives, rather than waiting for batch uploads.

With a new persona, the Device Integration Engineer, customers can now onboard, configure, and monitor devices - capabilities that were not offered in the past and were covered in other systems out side of SAP Asset Performance Management. This opens up new opportunities to get closer to the source of data, or even retrofit installing sensors that are required for maintenance purposes.

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Manage IoT Dashboards

For near real-time insights and reporting, the Cockpit gives you the flexibility and tools to manage and monitor device data, creating widget-based reports for individual or groups of devices. With this feature, reliability engineers can now access personalised, live, contextual IoT dashboards - unifying sensor data and events - so they detect anomalies immediately on critical assets, flexibly visualize data per their needs, and assist in driving fact-based maintenance decisions.

To quickly get started with a live data feed and exemplary dashboards, you can connect your smartphone in just a minute and explore. See how in the video:

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Manage Streaming Analytics

Streaming Rules enable enhanced condition monitoring with flow-based models to process time series data in near real-time at individual data point level. This allows for monitoring within the IoT platform, to derive new indicator values, and also triggering of rules within SAP Asset Performance Management. This continuous, real-time feedback loop allows reliability engineers to respond proactively to critical events and implement monitoring and dashboards themselves using low-code tools â€” capabilities not possible with batch-based monitoring. For more details, have a look at the What's new blog from the 2510 release.

 

For a quick glimpse in how it is working, you can watch this video:

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Map Devices to Technical Objects

To use the time series for asset management purposes, the sensors from the IoT platform need to be contextualized into the asset semantics using the Digital Twin Manager. The application allows to map devices and their sensors (the OT world) to their corresponding technical objects and indicators from SAP Asset Performance Management (the IT world). Once the connection is established, data is automatically made available into charts, rules engine, and stored into the data lake from SAP Asset Performance Management.

Navigate to technical objects along the technical object hierarchy

Assign measurements from a device to an indicator

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

IoT Platform Administration

Users seamlessly navigate to the applications with out-of-box configured Single Sign-On, and also for data archiving (see Digital Twin Manager), everything is setup automatically. However, some configurations are still relevant for Administrators and can be configured in the IoT Platform Administration application. Examples are the data forwarding between systems, or configuration of Certificate Authorities for device certificates administrators. With the Data Broker, administrators can now setup continuous data feeds between landscapes, i.e. to achieve a near real-time data ingestion into quality / test environments based on incoming data from the production environment.

What's next

Please stay tuned over the next weeks as we publish more articles showcasing the respective capabilities. You can't wait to get started? Check out this recently published blog that describes a brief end-to-end scenario from sensor to insight, using a free simulator app for your mobile phone. See how quick it is to monitor asset conditions, define failure thresholds, and generate maintenance requests using SAP Asset Performance Management.

entry.title: LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect (RSC) Implementation - Data Transfer to new Standard Fields
entry.content:
When implementing LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect (RSC) for the first time, you notice that some field mappings have hardcoded fields from SuccessFactors Recruiting, which cannot be modified to other fields. This happens because there's backend mapping between LinkedIn and SuccessFactors for certain fields. As LinkedIn expects to receive certain values for specific fields, an internal mapping defines how each value is sent. As a result, it is not possible to change the mapping to other Recruiting fields.

You can find the full list of field mappings and whether each one is editable here: Field Mapping Information

For example, industries and employmentStatus from LinkedIn are mapping to industry and classificationType accordingly in Recruiting, and the mapping cannot be changed.

This requirement can create implementation challenges, as some fields linked to these mappings are not used by customers, and they may have other standard or custom fields where the same information is stored.

This blog explains how to move the existing data into the fields required for the mapping using Integration Center. For example, if a customer does not use the employmentStatus standard field but has another field with the same information, they must still map and fill employmentStatus to implement LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect (RSC).

NOTES:

  • This integration needs experience with Integration Center and Recruiting configuration, and it is meant to be handled by Implementation Partners or Admin Users who have an implementation background;
  • The integration described below may behave in different ways on different systems. Please make sure to test all steps in a lower environment before moving anything to Production;
    • For better results, we suggest testing first with a small number of records before updating all of them.
  • Integration Center may not support updating all records in one single run if the number is higher than the tool's limit. We strongly recommend reviewing Integration Center limits before creating the integration: 2742107 - Integration Center: Frequently asked questions
  • As a best practice, avoid creating one integration for more than one field mapping, as this may cause performance timeouts.

STEPS:

  1. Go to Admin Center > Integration Center > My Integrations;
  2. "+ Create" button > More Integration Types;
  3. Select the following setup:
    • Trigger: Scheduled
    • Destination: SuccessFactors
    • Source: SuccessFactors
    • Format: OData v2
  4. Select the entity;
      • For Candidate Profile entity, you can use the entity CandidateLight to bypass required field validation
      • For Job Application, you can refer to the KBA Required attribute on Application fields via OData API - Recruiting Management
      • For Job Requisition, you can add the property "isDraft" to the mapping, making sure to pass TRUE. With this value, you can make your update without providing all mandatory values on the Job Requisition.
    • If the following criteria is not meet, the update may fail.
  5. On "Options" tab, fill all necessary fields
  6. On "Configure Fields" tab:
    1. Change the view to "Field Mapping View"
    2. Link the source field with the new standard field; - For example, you are mapping your existing standard OR custom fields that holds up the Employment Category to employmentStatus field, you need to link the existing field from the left column to the employmentStatus field in the right column. Here's an example from the columns (The entity here is Candidate):
      You need to drag and drop the field.
    3. Repeat the same steps to the ID field by linking the field from the left column to the right column
      • IDs per entity:
        • Candidate ID - candidateId
        • Job Application ID - applicationId
        • Job Requisition ID - jobReqId
    4. Once the mapping is done go to "Filter and Sort" and exclude any anonymized record, otherwise the system will considered anonymized records, which don't support updates:
      1. Click on "Browse" button
      2. Entity Tree View > Select the "Anonymized Flag"
      3. Add and filter by 0 (0 is the value for "Non-Anonymized)
    5. You can skip the "Scheduling" tab as the integration is meant to be executed one time only;
    6. "Review and Run" tab:
      • Click on "Run Now"
      • Wait the integration to complete
      • Verify any possible errors and fix

entry.title: Re: Client copy when table mismatched
entry.content:
When I couldn't clone due to:
Field MERKS1 in Table HRP1511 is different between systems, copy cannot proceed 

I was able to workaround this solution when in SAP Easy Clone tool, to go to hidden menu bar of Edit -> General Settings -> Easy Clone General Settings -> and setting Difference in a File / Field found == "Continue processing with a difference in a File /Field" then hitting save and running the clone again.  I hope this answer helps someone else out like it did for me.

For additional info, I was able to confirm field MERKS1 was of different length between 2 environments using:

SE14 --> HRP1511 --> Check (F8) -> Database Object -> Fields

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
Hi @Marco_Mueller 

I am the certification owner for BDC. I can answer your questions.

Passing grade for the BDC assessment is 60%. This is shown on the start page of the certification before you begin and it is also shown as a reminder if you fail.

After asking you a question, the AI will keep quiet while you provide your answer. You can speak for as long as you wish and the AI will never interrupt you. When you have finished answering, the AI will wait approx. 5 seconds and if you don't say anything else, it will assume you are finished and will then move on to the next question.

You submit the exam by pressing Save and View Analysis:

After a short wait, you see your score:



Once you reach the pass score you cannot take the assessment again (e.g. to improve your score). If you fail you can try as many times as you wish within the 2 hour time limit until you reach the pass score. 

You say you reached 80% - so you must have pressed the Save and View Analysis button because that is the only way you can see your score. But you say you failed.  Well, you certainly met the pass score. How were you informed that you failed?

entry.title: Re: Current Support Status of MultiCash Format in SAP S/4...
entry.content:
Good day @JuanseVal 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Bank Statement Processing, Map Format Data for Incoming Files from Banks, How to Create a Format Mapping, Data Format Conversion in Outbound and Inbound Transactions

Check out Blog: Bank statement in XML format

In summary to your questions, the public cloud does not support MultiCash and you cannot activate it as standard import format. For you to use MultiCash statements, you must transform the file preferably into CAMT.053 or MT940 before you import. The SAP integration Suite or an external converter will enable you do that. Your customer can consider XML mapping if they receive MultiCash in XML form.

This conversion method ensure you stick to the public cloudâ€™s clean-core approach, and it provides the standard integration pattern for banks that still provide MultiCash.

Let me know if you have further question on the CDS views creation.



Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Customer stock in custody
entry.content:
Materials are invoiced and ownership has legally passed to the customer, but physically they remain in your warehouse under your custody until the customer calls them off. You need visibility in SAP without keeping them on your companyâ€™s books.

So the recommended approach would be

Once the delivery is created, just save it and do not perform goods issue.  By doing so, that stock would be blocked for that customer and cannot be diverted to other sale orders or customers.   Of course, system will allow you to invoice before goods issue and for that, set routine 11 under "Copying requirements" in copy control configuration.  As and when, customer wanted to have, you can perform goods issue.

Now coming to your â€œcustomer plantâ€, the challenge I could see is you already created the sales order, delivery, goods issue, and invoice in SAP. Ownership has legally passed to the customer. You then â€œreceiveâ€ the stock into a nonâ€‘valuated custody plant for visibility. Later, the customer asks you to physically ship it. But: there is no open sales order anymore, and billing has already been done. So how do you create a delivery from the custody plant? Of course, here also, you can explore VL01NO to create another delivery from "customer plant".

To explore "Customer Plant" option, try with the below approach but I am not sure on this

Create a special plant, sometimes called a â€œcustomer plantâ€ or â€œcustody plantâ€. Assign it as nonâ€‘valuated in customizing so postings there donâ€™t hit your books. After the outbound delivery and goods issue from your normal plant, you immediately â€œreceiveâ€ the same material into this special plant. This way stock is visible in SAP under the same material number. It is tracked by quantity. It is not valuated (ownership is with the customer). When the customer requests delivery, you create a delivery from this custody plant to the customer. Here, I am not sure, with which movement type, system will allow you to perform Goods Issue. Test and explore with multiple permutation combination.

entry.title: Re: Need To Add a Custom Field into Import Supplier Invoices
entry.content:
Dear @jerinsteev,

Question 1.

Yes, but only in a very restricted way.

SAP explicitly documents that the Import Supplier Invoices app (F3041) can be extended with Custom Fields but only fields created with the business context Accounting: Coding Block

Key points from SAP Note:

  1. Create the custom fields in Custom Fields (F1481) with business context:
    • Accounting: Coding Block
  2. In the User Interfaces tab, enable: (This is the problem because I can't see it in the screenshots)
    • Manage Journal Entries
    • Manage Supplier Invoice
  3. Publish the field.
  4. Download a new template in Import Supplier Invoices app

More details below in SAP Note:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3452028

Question 2.

For adding CFL custom fields to the Import Supplier Invoices template, no additional extension objects, OData extensions, or communication scenarios are required

Question 3.

Yes, there is a very direct SAP Note on exactly this point.

Special G/L Indicator is not supported in Import Supplier Invoices app

More details from SAP Note and SAP Community:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3657638

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/payload-examples-for-api-journal-entry-post/ba-p/13392342

Also SAP Note documents that some fields in the template are visible but ignored during upload, and SAP plans to remove them from the template

More details below from SAP Note:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3613252

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Subcontracting delivery MESSAGE ME151 (0 item(s) posted)
entry.content:
Why it happens would be because of the following:

In a subcontracting PO, the finished material is ordered, but the BOM components must be assigned in the PO item (via item detail â†’ â€œComponentsâ€ tab). If components are not maintained, ME2O has nothing to deliver.

ME2O checks stock of the components in the supplying plant/storage location. If stock is in a different location or batch, the system wonâ€™t pick it.

Subcontracting delivery uses movement type 541 (transfer posting to subcontractor). If the delivery type or movement type customizing is incomplete, items wonâ€™t post.

entry.title: How template based approach is helping Life Sciences customers adopt SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
Life sciences industry is increasingly adopting public cloud solutions such as SAP Digital Manufacturing, to enable smart, connected factories, and enable next generation of AI innovations. While cloud solutions provide clear benefit in terms of scalability, no-technical debt, and rapid deployment â€“ the validation of these introduce unique challenges.

Public cloud solutions differ from traditional on-premises or private cloud solutions as the infrastructure and platform is supplier managed, and updates occur on supplierâ€™s schedule (quarterly for SAP Digital Manufacturing). Customers while inheriting many controls from supplier (SAP) remain accountable for compliance. This can result in ballooning validation costs, as with every new site and every release customers need to demonstrate that they continue to operate within regulations.

Here a template base validation approach provides a structured, repeatable strategy to address these challenges efficiently.

Core Principles for this approach

  1. Process first modular template:  The validation templates should focus on testing standardized, end-to-end processes (not technical UI screens). Customers may modularize these based on process (Dispensing, Sampling etc), so local rollouts validate only deltas to the module. The approach is based on performing validation of the global template once, and then validate deltas during rollouts, and releases
  2. Risk-based and outcome-focused validation:  As also recommended by GAMP V, a risk based approach should be applied to select what needs full local validation. A ranked and modular approach can be used to split validation into smaller risk-aligned lanes.
  3. Automate validation artifacts and test execution: Digitize test case management, traceability, and evidence capture. This allows validation templates to be rolled out with minimal manual documentation.
  4. Governance and shared responsibility: Clearly define roles for template owners, local leads, and cloud providers; document responsibilities in a RACI matrix.

Common challenges & mitigations

When implementing the template approach some challenges to lookout for:

  • Challenge: Templates are too rigid â€” sites need many exceptions, resulting in no cost savings .
  • Mitigation: Design configurable templates (parameters, toggles), and track which options cause site variance.
  • Challenge: Incomplete supplier qualification for cloud / third parties.
  • Mitigation: Document SLAs, security controls, SOC/ISO audits, and if possible perform on-site supplier assessment.
  • Challenge: Manual, paper-based validation artifacts that slow rollouts.
  • Mitigation: Use digital validation platforms and automate testing that can capture evidences (Tricentis Test Automation)
  • Challenge: Not taking advantage of fixed cloud release cadence.
  • Mitigation: Formalize release impact assessments and maintain a prioritized regression pack mapped to template processes. Allocate resources for validation in advance (as the schedule is known).

 

How DHC Uses and Extends the Template Approach

DHC, an SAP partner, has expanded these industry best practices to develop validation templates specific to SAP Digital Manufacturing and regulated industries. These templates have enabled regulated customers to validate SAP Digital Manufacturing and its underlying infrastructure efficiently, supporting global rollouts across multiple production sites while ensuring lower Total Cost of Validation.

A notable example is DHCâ€™s work with a regulated industry customer, where the validation templates developed during the pilot became the foundation for enterprise-wide rollout. These templates executed through agile sprints supported by an industrialized, repeatable validation process, helped customer roll out three templates covering different production types. As SAP Digital Manufacturing undergoes frequent major releases (quarterly), DHC implemented a change management process as a part of the template approach that leverages SAP Digital Manufacturingâ€™s Service Catalog and Whatâ€™s New viewer allowing quick and efficient change impact assessment. 

This industrialized approach towards change management and validation allows customers to remain compliant through frequent software updates associated with public cloud solutions.

 

Why this matters for life sciences

Life sciences organizations must reconcile fast cloud innovation with strict regulatory expectations. A template approach â€” when designed around processes, risk, and automated validation â€” provides the repeatability and auditability something that regulators expect. This balance of process discipline + modern tooling + governance is what SAP and our partners such as DHC recommend.

Partner Profile:

DHC Dr. Herterich & Consultants GmbH specializes in GxP compliance and the validation of IT systems in regulated industries. Further details - SAP Partner Finder

entry.title: Re: U.S SECURE 2.0 Act - Section 603
entry.content:
Hello @JimLee209,

You have the flexibility to configure Parameter 1 of payroll function P0169 to align with your specific business requirements. For instance, if you set it to END, and your payroll period ends on 01/15/2025, it is necessary to ensure that the BN603 option has a start date of 01/15/2025 or earlier.

Please note that there was a typo in the example date of KBA 3677876; it should have listed 12/28/2025 rather than 01/28/2025. This has been corrected in the updated version of KBA 3677876. Thank you for bringing this to our attention.
This example referenced a scenario where the configuration date on P0169 fell in the previous year within the payroll
period. 

Best regards,
Gisele

entry.title: Mastering the AI Mindset - Co-Creating the Future of AI & Customer Experience with SAP CX
entry.content:
Introduction

When looking back on the last few decades in the business world, we noticed revolutionary technologies have come along. Steam power changed the way we produce goods, electricity took scaling to a new level, and the internet reshaped the way we connect and do business and...here we go again - Artificial Intelligence is now changing how we behave and also do business. The reality is here: organizations and individuals must rapidly adapt, leveraging agility and resilience to augment human capabilities in every sales call, commerce site, and customer interaction; therefore, the question is: how your people and AI will co-create value together and what that means for the way you operate, decide, do busines, and will deliver results - going forward.

That said, in this blog, weâ€™ll explore the mindset shift required to fully embrace AI and show how SAP CX Business AI Capabilities - across SAP Commerce Cloud and Sales & Service Cloud (V1 and V2) - can become a catalyst for this transformation.

 

The Mindset Shift AI Demands

This shift is emotional before it is operational.

People's emotional responses can be intense when shifting to a more AI-driven work environment. Coming to terms with the idea that AI may replace them is something that strikes fear into the hearts of many, and will feel overwhelming for a few.  Others, however, will light up at the prospect of new ideas; it's natural for some to believe it may power their performance.

In fact, if we put it in perspective, humans have been adapting to AI since its boom, and here are some examples of human personal usage:

 

AI generated

 

Hence, that is where the bridge to business really begins. The same curiosity that drives us to adopt AI - to save time, learn something new, or make our lives a bit easier - is what companies need to encourage within their culture & mindset.

Leaders donâ€™t need to chase every shiny new tool. They need to notice the moments where AI can ease pressure, help people think differently, or give them back the time to focus on what actually matters. When those experiments start to feel natural, when curiosity becomes confidence, AI stops being some distant idea and simply becomes part of how the organization works.

Thatâ€™s the real mindset shift: when AI moves from concept to companion, enabling people and businesses to grow together.

The companies and teams will be led into the future, and the leaders who will thrive are the ones who help their teams move from fear to possibility, from control to collaboration, and from task to outcome-focused mindset.

 

Augmentation, not replacement.

Letâ€™s be clear: in the CX world, AI doesnâ€™t replace the human element â€” it elevates it.

AI takes away the repetitive, low-value tasks so people can focus on what customers truly care about, for example: empathy, transparency, judgment, wisdom, and trust - all uniquely human qualities.

Think of AI as a second brain: summarizing, suggesting, forecasting, preparing groundwork, and accelerating execution. When we embrace this partnership, the impact becomes visible across all CX areas:

 

  • Commerce: content that used to take weeks is now produced in hours.
  • Sales: teams are no longer stuck in spreadsheets - they have insights and preparation done for them.
  • Service: customers receive instant answers with human escalation when needed.

In essence, we start every task with a machine-generated foundation -  the â€œbare minimumâ€ already done, so humans can focus on what only humans can do: adding context, judgment, and real-life perspective.

AI frees people to do their best work, powered by human traits that technology can support but never replace.

 

SAP CX: Where the Mindset Meets the Workflow

There is a consistent message SAP CX AI connected to SAP Commerce Cloud, Sales Cloud, Service Cloud - AI works best when we redesign our processes to be around augmented work.

Examples of that mindset in action:

  • SAP Commerce Cloud: AI drafts product content, suggests improvements, guide and support the shopper relying on Agentic AI - while humans can focus on refining brand voice, enhancing experience & powerful personalization.
  • SAP Sales Cloud: AI highlights next steps, key signals, brainstorm discovery, quickly sum up key points & Agent AI supporting Quote creation from emails - while humans can focus on building relationships and closing more deals.
  • SAP Service Cloud: AI summarizes, proposes responses, suggests resolutions, and quickly categorizes incident requests via Machine Learning or GenAI - while humans can focus on handling tickets/cases with proper empathy and ease escalation.

Hence, the companies winning with SAP CX arenâ€™t â€œusing AIâ€œ. Theyâ€™re working with AI - challenging it, reimaging their business process and workflows, and partaking in the early adoption care programs as visionaries together - with SAP.

 

Purpose-built AI that adapts to your unique challenges â€“ A simple and exemplary Self-Check

If your AI initiative is stuck, itâ€™s usually because one of these six elements is weak:

-> If you canâ€™t say â€œyesâ€ to most of these, pause the build. Fix the foundation. Then scale.

 

Change Management: The Decisive Factor in AI Adoption Success

Coming from the world of the known and complex change management area, AI is also technology (enhanced one, though) so the transformation is not just about rolling out new systems, it's changing people's mindset and underlying behaviours.

Thefore, also here, the foundation is imperative to address - What really gets results is explaining why AI matters, training people to think alongside it, starting small and showing off the benefit, like measuring outcomes, and addittionally, celebrate stories that show the human and AI working together, which is basically what gets people on board, and makes them feel they have a place in the future.

In short terms, here is what we may explore:

  • Explain the why, not just the what
  • Train people to think with AI, not fight against it
  • Start small and show quick wins
  • Measure Adoption & outcomes, not just usage in testing AI
  • Celebrate human + AI success stories

You see, itâ€™s not because AI is complicated that people resist it - is usually because they don't see themselves in the picture. As a leader, you have to show them that there is a place for them.

 

Daily Rituals to Embed the Mindset 

Small daily rituals are great for embedding a mindset, because practice makes it perfect:

  • Begin workshops or internal discussion with: What could CX AI do for us in our line of business? Quick wins? Low complexity use case to start with?
  • Practice active listening in daily interaction:  How people are reacting â€“ what is their sentiment â€“ feeling about the AI value and adoption?
  • Leverage providers to learn at every interaction:  Ask your AI provider - how can you help my company, my business? Workshops, sharing experience & support -  SAP has been doing it! Check here some examples of Commerce Cloud or Sales & Service Cloud adoption journey playbooks and AI mindset workshops are ready for you!
  •  Regular reviews, ask: has AI improved our outcome? Analyze the results & compare â€“ current vs target.

To ground this in practice, the image below summarizes some essential Doâ€™s and Donâ€™ts that can help teams adopt AI with clarity and focus:

 

AI generated.

 

 

Quick Wins First, Ambition Second

To reinforce what weâ€™ve discussed so far â€” and to avoid chaos or project setbacks â€” itâ€™s essential to focus and prioritize quick wins. AI can truly be a game-changer, driving impact in areas like summarization, content creation, search and personalization, request classification, recommendations, and automation of repetitive tasks. Start by mapping your quick wins, prove the value early, and then scale with confidence.

It is almost certain that massive â€œAI for everything now!â€ initiatives often lead to disorder rather than progress. Sustainable success starts with a strong foundation and clear priorities.

 

Useful Assets & Recommended Readings

  • Artificial intelligence for the real world: A blueprint for business integration
  • SAP research reveals AI to deliver a 31% return on investment
  • A practical guide for maximizing AI ROI
  • Economic Validation Study: Analyzing the Economic Benefits of Using AI-Powered SAP CX Solutions Natively Connected to SAP ERP

 

Closing: The Future Is Not Human vs Machine â€“ at least not today ğŸ™‚

The companies that will thrive in the future are those that will say "AI is a tool that works -  for me", "AI can make suggestions, but I'm the one who creates", "AI can speed up processes and I'll take the lead".  We are still in the Copilot / Second brain Era - Let's enjoy it and make a valuable use of the AI attached to our business activities.

â€¦.which leads to the final message: It's not about outsmarting the technology; mastering AI is really about changing your way of thinking, learning, and working. Those who seize an AI-driven mindset will move more swiftly, serve better, and create CX experiences that are etched in their customers' minds.

entry.title: Calling SAP API Management from SAP Cloud Integration Using API Proxy URL & OAuth Authorization.
entry.content:
This guide explains how to connect SAP API Management (APIM) with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) using an API Proxy URL secured by OAuth 2.0 authentication.

NorthWind Link: https://services.odata.org/northwind/northwind.svc/ 

1. Create API Provider.

2. Create API Proxy - To Generate an OAuth Authentication Token.

3. Add Policy - To generate OAuth 2.0 Authentication.

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <Operation>GenerateAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/>
       <SupportedGrantTypes>
           <GrantType>client_credentials</GrantType>
       </SupportedGrantTypes>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

4. Create API Provider.

5. Add Policies to the API Proxy created to call the OData. 

Verify API Key - To verify the key which you are going to pass while calling the API.

<!--Specify in the APIKey element where to look for the variable containing the api key--> 
<VerifyAPIKey async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' 
xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<APIKey ref='request.header.apikey '/>
</VerifyAPIKey>

OAuth 2.0 - To verify the OAuth Token generated.

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <!-- valid values are GenerateAccessToken, GenerateAccessTokenImplicitGrant, GenerateAuthorizationCode ,
    RefreshAccessToken , VerifyAccessToken , InvalidateToken , ValidateToken  -->
   <Operation>VerifyAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/><SupportedGrantTypes/>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

Assign Message:

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="true" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
    <Remove>   
     	<Headers>      
			<Header name="Authorization"></Header>   
          </Headers>
     </Remove> 
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request"></AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

Update >> Save >> Deploy

6. Create Product & Add both the API Proxies.

7. Create a Subscription for the Product created.

Copy the API URL, KEY and Secret for future use.

8. Create an Integration Flow.

Content Modifier: Pass Authentication Details in Header

  • client_secret: from the subscription 
  • client_id: from the subscription 
  • response_type: token
  • grant_type: client_credentials
  • Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

Body: grant_type=${header.grant_type}&client_id=${header.client_id}&client_secret=${header.client_secret} 

Request Reply - HTTP 1: For Token Verification.

Content Modifier 2: For the Passing of Authorisation and API Key.

Content Modifier 3: Pass Bearer Token

Header: Bearer ${header.Access_Token_Value}

Request Reply - HTTP 2: Pass the endpoint URL of the API Proxy.

It's time to test.

For Token generation:

OAuth 2.0

Hit Send >> 200 OK

Debug >>

Trace:

The integration between SAP Cloud Integration and SAP API Management using OAuth 2.0 has been configured and tested successfully.

entry.title: Re: COMMIT WORK AND WAIT slows down system performances
entry.content:
COMMIT WORK AND WAIT slows down the system.
It forces SAP to fully complete the update task before moving to the next material that creates amassive bottleneck issue. If it's only 20k you can just use Commit work, if it's more than that you can split in containers and do parallel task which will be easier. I have faced one issue long time back, this is how i resolved.

entry.title: Re: Project Billing for Customer Projects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Hello @gireeshbt1,

This can already be done. Quantities are processed by Project Billing and, when properly configured, are transferred to the subsequent Sales Billing procedure. When setting up the Billing Profile, the following options are available:

  1. Transfer Costs Only
  2. Transfer Costs and Quantity
  3. For Costs <> 0: Transfer Costs and Quantity
  4. For Quantity <> 0: Transfer Costs and Quantity
  5. Transfer Quantity Only

Best regards,

Andreas
